questions.text: In a child, with a unilateral shrunken kidney, the following test was performed to assess the function of the kidney. Identify the test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DTPA renogram Renal scans provide both functional and anatomic information. preferred modality in infants and children because of reduced radiation exposure compared with CT Renal scans using the radioisotope technetium Tc-99m mertiatide (Tc-99mMAG3) assess renal excretory function. It is the study of choice in differentiating between obstructive and nonobstructive hydronephrosis in infants and children and can also identify a difference in function between the two kidneys Imaging studies- Radionuclide Studies-- Radionuclide studies can measure renal function. Technetium diethylene triamine Penta acetic acid (99mTc – DTPA) (dynamic renal scan) is freely filtered by the glomerulus and not reabsorbed and is used to estimate GFR. Technetium is dimercaptosuccinic ( 99mTc – DMSA ) (State renal scan) is bound to the tubules and provides an assessment of functional renal mass . Example the DMSA SCAN OF a 31-month-old girl with recurrent UTI. The right kidney has a normal size with a cortical defect in the lower pole. The left kidney is small-sized with cortical loss in the lower part which can be due to cortical scar or duplicated collecting system. Radioiodinated (131I) ortho iodohippurate is secreted into the renal tubules and assesses renal plasma flow (RPF). Ultrasonography Kidney size can be determined; a kidney less than 9 cm in length indicates significant irreversible renal disease. b. A difference in the size of more than 1.5 cm between the two kidneys is observed in unilateral renal disease. Intravenous Urography (IVP) Rapid sequence IVP is done for Renal artery stenosis CT urography: Urography uses imaging and contrast material to evaluate or detect blood in urine kidney or bladder stones, and cancer in the urinary tract. Urography is often performed using X-ray (IVP), CT, or MRI. Cystoscopy: It is an endoscopy of the urinary bladder via the urethra carried ant with a cystoscope. It can be a flexible or rigid cystoscope. Renal Biopsy

questions.text: You are attending medicine rounds in the ICU. You come across a 48-year-old male is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis in septic shock . He is started on inotropic support. His weight is 60kg and serum creatinine is 3.2mg/dl Blood culture shows the presence of Acinetobacter sensitive to the following Vancomycin Moxifloxacin Telavancin Gentamicin The consultant asks you which of the following is least nephrotoxic and does not require dose modification in this patient. What will be your response?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Moxifloxacin Renal dysfunction has little effect on Moxifloxacin clearance and no dose adjustment is required in renal failure. However, it causes modest QT prolongation and should be used with caution in patients receiving other QT-prolonging drugs Vancomycin can cause nephrotoxicity and ‘ red man syndrome Aminoglycosides are known to cause nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity Telavancin can cause QT prolongation, taste disturbances, and nephrotoxicity

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presented with a history of passing high-colored urine over the last 2 days. On examination pitting pedal edema is present. BP-154/100mmHg. S creatinine is 2.1mg/dl and urine shows the presence of RBC casts. History of sore throat 2 weeks ago. In this condition, immune deposition occurs at what place?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Acute GN Acute Poststreptococcal GN Postinfectious glomerulonephritis occurs as a sequela of disease caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and helminths. It is the most common cause of GN in childhood. Nephritis develops 1 –3 weeks after pharyngeal (more common in winter) or cutaneous infection with (more common in summer ) ‘nephritogenic’ strains of group A beta–hemolytic streptococci. Diagnosis depends on a positive pharyngeal or skin culture, rising antibody titers, and hypocomplementemia. Renal biopsy reveals diffuse proliferative GN. Pathology. Diffuse proliferative disease with mesangial and endothelial hypercellularity. Electron microscopy-dense deposits are seen in the subepithelial area (humps), sub-endothelial area, mesangial, and sometimes intra-membranous. Clinical features and diagnosis The typical clinical presentation is a sudden onset of hematuria and edema. The characteristic, but not diagnostic, laboratory profile is azotemia, hypocomplementemia, hematuria, leukocyturia, and proteinuria. Supporting data include elevated titers of antistreptolysin 0, anti-hyaluronidase, and anti-deoxyribonuclease B antibodies, all of which suggest preceding streptococcal infection. Clinical course and diagnosis The typical course of acute disease is recovery, particularly among children. Acute nephritis resolves with amelioration of edema and hypertension 1-3 weeks after onset. Proteinuria may persist for several months, exacerbated by erect posture and exercise. Microscopic hematuria similarly disappears slowly over a period of several months. CKD is rare in childhood PSGN but may be seen in adult-onset PSGN. Investigations Best Initial Test: Urine analysis. Most accurate test: Biopsy (but usually not needed) Indications of Biopsy H/O prior hematuria (as usually, PSGN doesn’t recur, recurrent hematuria should point to a different diagnosis) No improvement within 2 weeks The complement level is decreased ( C3, CH50). Persistently low complement level beyond 6 weeks. Therapy. Hypertension must be treated aggressively, Furosemide or bumetanide is required for the underlying edema-inducing disease. Antibiotic - penicillin. Prophylaxis following post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is not indicated because recurrences are exceedingly rare. Immunosuppressive agents or corticosteroids have no therapeutic role.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with episodes of gross hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection 3 days ago. Which of the following immunofluorescence patterns will be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A IgA Nephropathy (Berger’s Disease) This case scenario is indicative of IgA nephropathy. Immunofluorescence will show IgA deposits in mesangium as seen in option A Clinical Features Typically hematuria occurs within 1 to 3 days after URTI. This is the most common form of primary glomerular disease in the world usually aged 2nd – 3rd decade. Male > femal This is the most common form of primary glomerular disease causing hematuria in children in the world. (MCQ) It progresses to end-stage renal disease in 20 to 40% of patients affected over a 20 years period. Gross, intermittent hematuria, which is glomerular, is the presenting symptom. There is the presence of abnormal proteinuria Histologically, IgA nephropathy may show mesangial widening and focal and segmental inflammation. Diffuse mesangial proliferation or crescentic glomerulonephritis may also be present. Immunofluorescence shows mesangial deposition of IgA often with C3 and properdin. Early components of the classical complement pathway (C1q or C4) are usually not seen. Electron microscopy confirms electron-dense deposits in the mesangium that may extend to the subendothelial area of adjacent capillary walls in a small subset of cases, usually those with focal proliferation. IgA nephropathy is a type of mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis with IgA deposition in the mesangium. Example of Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis. Causes Typical pathological findings Typical clinical presentation IgA nephropathy HSP Proliferation of mesangial cells and deposition of IgA in matrix Hematuria Proteinuria Hypertension

questions.text: A 20 year old male presented with a history of recurrent episodes of hematuria for the last one week. He also gives a history of having a sore throat 10 days ago and says that the hematuria started 2-3 days after the sore throat. There is no history of oliguria/pedal edema. Laboratory investigations revealed 1+ proteinuria and plenty of RBCs in urine. 24 hr urine protein was 180 mg/day. Serum creatinine was 0.76mg/dl. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IgA Nephropathy This is a case of IgA nephropathy. Points in favor of diagnosis are History Of preceding URTI (history of sore throat) and development of hematuria in 2-3 days following the episode URTI –“synpharyngitic hematuria” Presence of macroscopic hematuria Nonnephrotic range proteinuria Immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy is characterized by predominant IgA deposition in the glomerular mesangium It is one of the most common causes of glomerulonephritis in the world Although IgA nephropathy is a limited nonsystemic renal disease, many systemic illnesses are sporadically associated with mesangial IgA deposition. Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), a systemic illness, has been closely linked to IgA nephropathy Classification system followed is called OXFORD CLASSIFICATION- MEST-C OXFORD CLASSIFICATION OF IGA NEPHROPATHY MEST DESCRIPTION SCORE M Mesangial Hypercellularity MO: <50% Glomeruli M1: >50% Glomeruli E Endocapillary Hypercellularity EO: Absent E1: Present S Segmental Glomerulosclerosis SO: Absent S1: Present T Tubular Atrophy TO: Absent or <25% tubules T1:26-50% tubules T2: >50% tubules C Crescent CO: Absent C1:1-24% Glomeruli C2: >25%

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. PSGN presents 2-4 weeks after URTI with hematuria In this case there is synpharyngitic hematuria Option: C. Good pastures syndrome presents with both pulmonary and renal involvement. Option: D. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with nephrotic range proteinuria.

questions.text: A 12 year old male child presented with a history of the passage of cola-colored urine, edema, and hypertension. There was a history of preceding skin infection prior to 10 days ago. Which of the following titers can be elevated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above This is a case of Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis The classic presentation is an Acute nephritic picture with hematuria, pyuria, red blood cell casts, edema, hypertension, and oliguric renal failure, which may be severe enough to appear as RPGN. Systemic symptoms of headache, malaise, anorexia, and flank pain (due to swelling of the renal capsule) are reported in as many as 50% of cases. 90% of patients will have a depressed CH50 and decreased levels of C3 with normal levels of C4 . Positive rheumatoid factor (30–40%), cryoglobulins, circulating immune complexes (60–70%), and ANCA against myeloperoxidase (10%) are also reported. Positive cultures for streptococcal infection are inconsistently present (10–70%), but increased titers of ASO ( 30%), anti-DNAse (70%) , or anti-hyaluronidase antibodies (40%) can help confirm the diagnosis.

Extraedge:

The streptomyces test, which measures five different streptococcal antibodies, is positive in more than 95 percent of patients due to pharyngitis and approximately 80 percent of those with skin infections. It includes the following antibodies: Anti-streptolysin (ASO) Anti-hyaluronidase (AHase) Anti-streptokinase (ASKase) Anti-nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotides (anti-NAD) Anti-DNase B antibodies These antibodies can also be measured individually. After a pharyngeal infection, the ASO , anti-DNase B , anti-NAD, and AHase titers are commonly elevated. In comparison, only the anti-DNase B and AHase titers are typically increased after a skin infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, smoker presented with a history of recurrent hemoptysis. There is no history of fever, night sweats, or loss of weight and appetite. Lab investigations revealed rbc casts in urine. A renal biopsy was done which showed linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Goodpasture's syndrome GOOD PASTURES syndrome is a pulmonary-renal syndrome Patients who develop autoantibodies directed against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When they present with lung hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, they have a pulmonary-renal syndrome called Goodpasture's syndrome. The target epitopes for this autoimmune disease lie in the quaternary structure of the a3 NC1 domain of collagen IV. The epitopes are normally sequestered in the collagen IV hexamer and can be exposed to infection, smoking, oxidants, or solvents. Goodpasture's syndrome appears in two age groups: in young men in their late twenties and in men and women in their sixties and seventies. Younger patients are more likely to present with the full Goodpasture's syndrome, with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria, and older patients are more likely to present with isolated glomerulonephritis. Hemoptysis is largely confined to smokers, and those who present with lung hemorrhage as a group do better than older populations who have prolonged, asymptomatic renal injury.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with rapidly progressive renal failure. Urine routine showed the presence of hematuria and few pus cells. A Renal biopsy was done which showed the presence of crescents. Immunofluorescence showed granular immune deposits. All the following can be considered a differential diagnosis in this case EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis This patient has presented with Rapidly progressive renal failure associated with Crescent formation . This points towards the diagnosis of Rapidly progressive Glomerulonephritis. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a pauci immune ANCA associated vasculitis in which Does not has immune deposits TYPES OF RPGN - Type 1: Anti-GBM antibody disease Type 2: Immune complex - ● IgA nephropathy ● postinfectious glomerulonephritis ● lupus nephritis ● cryoglobulinemia. Type 3: Pauci-immune ● ANCA-positive- Wegener's, microscopic polyangiitis or Churg Straus ● ANCA-negative, pauci-immune RPGN Type 4: Double-antibody positive disease - Type 4 has features of both types 1 and 3. Idiopathic* AS this patient has evidence of immune complex deposits on immunofluorescence, the differentials that can be considered among the options are SLE Post-infectious IgA Nephropathy

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, D- Type 2 RPGN with Granular immune deposits

questions.text: Consider the following statements 1. Tram Tracking is seen in Type 1 MPGN 2. Type 2 MPGN includes dense deposit disease 3. Patients with MPGN are at very less risk of recurrence in transplanted renal allografts 4. Goods Pastures syndrome is an example of Type 2 RPGN+C6
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2 are true Tram track appearance which appears as splitting of the GBM is seen in Type 1 MPGN.It is a true statement Dense deposit disease is type 2 MPGN. It is a true statement Although all primary renal diseases can recur over time in transplanted renal allografts, patients with MPGN are well known to be at risk for not only a histological recurrence but also a clinically significant recurrence with loss of graft function, Therefore this is a false statement Goods Pastures syndrome is an example of Type 1 RPGN (not type 2 as given in the option), It is a kind of type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by linear deposition of IgG +/- C3 along the GBM. Therefore it is a false statement

Extraedge:

MPGN was classified into type I, type II, and type III Based on Electron Microscopy .but this is not used nowadays. Classification based on Immunofluorescence microscopy is being used these days MPGN type I -discrete immune deposits in the mesangium and subendothelial space MPGN type II-MPGN type II (dense deposit disease [DDD]) is characterized by continuous, dense ribbon-like deposits along the basement membranes of the glomeruli, tubules, and Bowman's capsule MPGN type III- MPGN type III is similar to MPGN type I except that subepithelial deposits are noted as well as subendothelial deposits Types of Crescentic Glomerulonephritis Anti GBM disease Immune complex-mediated injury Pauci Immune Necrotising and Crescentic GN Idiopathic
